head.title: Photoredox-Catalyzed α-Aminoalkylcarboxylation of Allenes with CO2 | Organic Letters

meta.content: Photoredox-Catalyzed α-Aminoalkylcarboxylation of Allenes with CO2

The photoredox-catalyzed α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of aryl allenes with CO2 and N,N-dimethylanilines is reported for the first time (26 examples, up to 96% yield). In the case of electron-deficient allenes, good regioselectivity was observed (up to 94:6), exclusively generating kinetic products over thermodynamic products. This protocol is a novel synthetic method for highly functionalized β,γ-unsaturated γ-aminobutyric esters.

div.span: Supporting Info (1)
SUBJECTS:

div.p:
The photoredox-catalyzed α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of aryl allenes with CO
2
and
N
,
N
-dimethylanilines is reported for the first time (26 examples, up to 96% yield). In the case of electron-deficient allenes, good regioselectivity was observed (up to 94:6), exclusively generating kinetic products over thermodynamic products. This protocol is a novel synthetic method for highly functionalized β,γ-unsaturated γ-aminobutyric esters.

γ-Aminobutyric acid is the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the mammalian central nervous system.
(1)
For this reason, the synthesis of structurally diverse γ-aminobutyric acid derivatives has been considered important in the pharmaceutical field.
(2)
In particular, various γ-aminobutyric acids bearing a tertiary carbon center at the β-position such as pregabalin,
(3)
baclofen,
(4)
phenibut,
(5)
and rolipram
(6)
have been investigated (
Figure
1
). In this regard, more structurally diverse, β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid derivatives have been developed to expand the potential bioactive pharmaceutical library.
(7)
Figure 1. Important β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acids in the pharmaceutical field.

Typical approaches have been developed through the Michael addition of carbonyl compounds to β-substituted nitroalkenes or the conjugate addition of nitromethane to α,β-unsaturated aldehydes.
(7a−d)
Another approach involves the photocatalytic radical conjugate addition of α,β-unsaturated compounds to amines.
(7e−i)
Recently, the visible-light-mediated difunctionalization of alkenes with CO
2
and various radical sources to obtain valuable carboxylic acids has received increasing attention.
(8)

Among the developed methods, the photoredox-catalyzed α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of electron-deficient alkenes with CO
2
in the presence of 1,2,3,5-tetrakis(carbazol-9-yl)-4,6-dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN) for γ-aminobutyric acid synthesis was independently developed by Wu and Xi (
Scheme 1
a).
(8c,e)
Very recently, the photoredox-catalyzed α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of activated alkenes with α-amino acids as a bifunctional reagent for γ-aminobutyric acid synthesis was reported by Yu and Cheng and Sun (
Scheme 1
a).
(8a,h)
However, β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid synthesis with CO
2
remains a great challenge due to the utilization of β-substituted alkenes with high reduction potential.
(9)
We envisioned that the photocatalytic α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of allenes with CO
2
and amines would serve as an ideal approach to deliver a novel γ-aminobutyric acid through the incorporation of the ethylene moiety at the β-position. Allenes, as special and versatile synthons with structural diversity, have received much attention in organic chemistry.
(10)

div.div:
Scheme 1. Sustainable Synthetic Route to γ-Amino Acid Derivatives with CO
2

div.p:
Although various allene difunctionalization methods have been investigated, few studies have been developed on the transition-metal-catalyzed difunctionalization of allenes with CO
2
for unsaturated carboxylic acid derivatives.
(11)
To the best of our knowledge, there have been no examples demonstrating the photocatalytic difunctionalization of allenes with CO
2
in a redox-neutral fashion. Herein we report the visible-light-mediated α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of aryl allenes with CO
2
and amines for β,γ-unsaturated γ-aminobutyric ester synthesis (
Scheme 1
b). This reaction is the first example of the photoredox-catalyzed difunctionalization of aryl allenes with CO
2
. Compared with the photocatalytic difunctionalization of alkenes with CO
2
,
(8)
the photocatalytic difunctionalization of allenes with CO
2
is more challenging due to their regioselectivity control issues.
(10,11)
A previous report indicated that the combination of a photocatalyst and base was important for regioselective radical addition to 2,3-allenoates.
(12)
Encouraged by this result, we initially investigated the reaction by using 4-trifluoromethylphenylallene
1a
as a model substrate with
N
,
N
-4-trimethylaniline
2a
as a radical source in the presence of 1 mol % Ir(dF(CF
3
)ppy)
2
(dtbpy)·PF
6
when using 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP) and a base under 15 W blue light-emitting diode (LED) irradiation at room temperature with CO
2
at atmospheric pressure (
Table
1
). We examined the reaction with bases such as CsOH·H
2
O, NaOAc, and K
2
HPO
4
(

1
, entries 1–3). In base screening, K
2
HPO
4
showed the best regioselectivity compared with other bases, although the yield slightly decreased. Next, we tested some other photocatalysts. Ir(dF(CF
3

2

, Ir(ppy)

6
, Ir(ppy)
3
, 1,2,3,5-tetrakis(carbazol-9-yl)-4,6-dicyanobenzene (4CzIPN), and (2,3,4,6)-3-benzyl-2,4,5,6-tetra(9
H
-carbazol-9yl)benzonitrile (4CzBnBN) gave relatively low regioselectivities and yields (
Table
1
, entries 4–8). To improve the selectivity of the kinetic product
3aa

Table
1

Table

N

N

Table

Table
1
, entries 13 and 14).

div.p:
Next, the reaction scope was studied with aryl allenes
1
and
2a
(
Scheme 3
). Hammett σ
m/p
values could be in accord with the selectivity of compounds
3
and

under the applied reaction conditions.
(14)
Electron-deficient phenylallenes with positive σ values undergo regioselective α-aminoalkylcarboxylation regardless of the substitution pattern. Phenylallenes bearing highly electron-withdrawing groups such as trifluoromethyl (
1b
), cyano (
1c
), keto carbonyl (
1d
), or ester groups (
1e
) at the para or meta position in the benzene ring were effective at giving the desired kinetic products in good yield with good regioselectivity (
3/4ba–3/4ea
). The introduction of weakly electron-withdrawing substituents, such as chloro (

–

/

1m

1n
–

3
/

–

). Electron-neutral and electron-donating-group-substituted benzyl radicals with high reduction potentials (−1.43 V vs standard calomel electrode (SCE) for the H benzyl radical analog and −1.75 V vs SCE for the
p
-OMe benzyl radical analog) were difficult to reduce by Ir(dF(CF

((

(9,15a)
Fortunately, it is presumed that allenes are easily reduced via an allyl-benzyl anion intermediate. When using 1,1-diaryl-substituted allenes at room temperature, a thermodynamically favorable product was obtained in moderate yield with excellent regioselectivity (
4pa
–
qa
). The electron density and structure of aryl allenes have a strong effect on the regioselectivity. Unfortunately, the utilization of ethyl-2,3-butadienoate did not lead to the desired products. (See
Scheme S1
in the
Supporting Information

div.p:
To gain insight into the efficiency of the α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of allenes with CO
2
, preliminary mechanistic experiments were conducted (
Scheme 4
). Continuous-light irradiation was an essential factor preventing hydroaminoalkylation.
(8c)
Stern–Volmer luminescence studies confirm that the light-activated Ir photocatalyst ((
E
1/2
Ir(III)*/Ir(II)) = +1.21 V vs SCE in MeCN)
(15)
was quenched by
2a
(
E
oxp
= +0.74 V vs SCE) rather than
1a
(
Scheme 4
; see
Figures S1 and S2
in the
Supporting Information
). When the radical scavenger 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperdinyloxyl (TEMPO) was used as an additive in the α-aminoalkylcarboxylation, the desired products were not observed. The radical adduct was detected by high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS) (
Scheme 4
and
Figure S3
in the
Supporting Information
). This result indicates that α-aminoalkylcarboxylation might rely on the radical pathway. The isotope-labeling experiments with D
2
O instead of CO
2
showed that benzyl allyl anion species were present in the catalytic cycle (
Scheme 4
; see
Figure S4
in the
Supporting Information
).

div.div: Scheme 4. Mechanistic Studies

div.p:
On the basis of the experimental results and the related refs
(10,12,and16)
, the proposed mechanism of the regioselective α-aminoalkylcarboxylation to aryl allenes is outlined in
Scheme 5
. The α-aminomethyl radical (
2′′
), which is produced by a photoexcited photocatalyst and base, undergoes addition to the central carbon of the allenes (
1a
) to give a radical delocalized intermediate (
A
). A subsequent single-electron transfer (SET) between A and the reduced photocatalyst Ir(II) gives the delocalized allyl-benzyl carbanion. The carbanion intermediates (
B
) attack CO
2
as nucleophiles, affording the expected β,γ-unsaturated γ-aminobutyric esters (
3a
) after treatment with TMSCHN
2
. The photocatalyst was regenerated by SET in the catalytic cycle. A gram-scale reaction was readily conducted. (See
Scheme S4
in the
Supporting Information
.) To demonstrate the utility of this reaction, the unsaturated γ-aminobutyric ester
3aa
was reduced by lithium aluminum hydride (LAH) to form δ-amino alcohol
6
. (See
Scheme S5
in the
Supporting Information
.)

div.div: Scheme 5. Proposed Mechanism

div.p:
In summary, we demonstrated the photoredox-catalyzed intermolecular α-aminoalkylcarboxylation of aryl allenes with CO
2
and amines in a redox-neutral fashion for the first time. Twenty-six examples of various aryl allenes and amines were demonstrated to afford good isolated yields (up to 96%). Electron-deficient substituted aryl allenes show great regioselectivity. This sustainable process is the general synthetic method of unsaturated γ-aminobutyric esters. α-Aminoalkylcarboxylation has the advantages of step and atom economy and mild conditions. The application and detailed reaction mechanism are currently ongoing.

Stress-induced elevations of γ-aminobutyric acid type A receptor-active steroids in the rat brain
Purdy, Robert H.; Morrow, A. Leslie; Moore, Perry H, Jr.; Paul, Steven M.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
(
1991
),
88
(
10
),
4553-7
CODEN:
PNASA6
; ISSN:
0027-8424
.
A 3α-hydroxy A-ring-reduced metabolite of progesterone, 3α-hydroxy-5α-pregnan-20-one (allopregnanolone), and one of deoxycorticosterone (DOC), 3α,21-dihydroxy-5α-pregnan-20-one (allotetrahydroDOC), are among the most potent known ligands of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors designated GABAA in the central nervous system. With specific RIAs, rapid (<5 min) and robust (4-20-fold) increases of allopregnanolone and allotetrahydroDOC were detected in the brain (cerebral cortex and hypothalamus) and in plasma of rats after exposure to ambient temp. swim stress. Neither steroid was detectable in the plasma of adrenalectomized rats either before or after swim stress. However, allopregnanolone, but not allotetrahydroDOC, was still present in the cerebral cortex (>3 ng/g) after adrenalectomy. These data demonstrate the presence of allopregnanolone and allotetrahydroDOC in brain and show that acute stress results in a rapid increase of these neuroactive steroids to levels known to modulate GABAA receptor function.

A review with refs. γ-Amino acids have attracted considerable attention as biol. active compds. in the central nervous system (CNS) of mammals. Over the last few years, significant interest in the stereoselective synthesis and practical application of linear and cyclic chiral γ-amino acids in the synthesis and design of α,β- and β,γ-hybrid peptides with definite secondary structures and design of nanotubes has been reported, thus demonstrating the theor. interest and the practical importance of γ-amino acids. An overview of synthetic approaches to linear and cyclic chiral γ-amino acids and derivs. is presented. Data on the practical applications of γ-amino acids are also discussed.

A review. The anticonvulsant drug (S)-(+)-3-isobutyl-γ-aminobutyric acid ((S)-(+)-3-isobutyl-GABA, Lyrica) was developed from a study of fundamental science, which took an unexpected course. The activity of Lyrica was found to be unrelated to the originally anticipated activation of L-glutamic acid decarboxylase and the increase in the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA; instead, it antagonizes a calcium ion channel, which inhibits the release of the excitatory neurotransmitter L-glutamate. The ultimate effect, however, is the same.

Baclofen, a new antispastic drug. A controlled, multicenter trial in patients with multiple sclerosis
Sachais B A; Logue J N; Carey M S
Archives of neurology

1977

(
7

422-8
ISSN:

.
A double-blind, five-week, multicenter trial was conducted to compare the effect of baclofen, a unique amino acid derivative, with that of placebo in the treatment of 106 patients with spasticity secondary to multiple sclerosis. A spasticity assessment method that included a neurological examination, physicians' clinical impressions of changes during treatment, and a patient's self-evaluation was used to determine efficacy. This method showed baclofen (70 to 80 mg daily maximum, titrated) is effective relative to placebo in relieving symptoms of spasticity, such as flexor spasms, pain and stiffness, resistance to passive joint movements, and tendon stretch reflexes. Patient self-evaluation results also showed a significant reduction in clonus. Side effects were generally mild and transient.

A review. Phenibut (β-phenyl-γ-aminobutyric acid HCl) is a neuro-psychotropic drug that was discovered and introduced into clin. practice in Russia in the 1960s. It has anxiolytic and nootropic (cognition enhancing) effects. It acts as a GABA-mimetic, primarily at GABAB and, to some extent, at GABAA receptors. It also stimulates dopamine receptors and antagonizes β-phenethylamine (PEA), a putative endogenous anxiogenic. The psychopharmacol. activity of phenibut is similar to that of baclofen, a p-Cl-deriv. of phenibut. This article reviews the structure-activity relationship of phenibut and its derivs. Emphasis is placed on the importance of the position of the Ph ring, the role of the carboxyl group, and the activity of optical isomers. Comparison of phenibut with piracetam and diazepam reveals similarities and differences in their pharmacol. and clin. effects. Phenibut is widely used in Russia to relieve tension, anxiety, and fear, to improve sleep in psychosomatic or neurotic patients; as well as a pre- or post-operative medication. It is also used in the therapy of disorders characterized by asthenia and depression, as well as in post-traumatic stress, stuttering, and vestibular disorders.

The antidepressant and antiinflammatory effects of rolipram in the central nervous system
Zhu, Jie; Mix, Eilhard; Winblad, Bengt
CNS Drug Reviews

A review. Rolipram is a selective inhibitor of phosphodiesterases (PDE) IV, esp. of the subtype PDE IVB. These phosphodiesterases are responsible for hydrolysis of the cyclic nucleotides cAMP and cGMP, particularly in nerve and immune cells. Consequences of rolipram-induced elevation of intracellular cAMP are increased synthesis and release of norepinephrine, which enhance central noradrenergic transmission, and suppress expression of proinflammatory cytokines and other mediators of inflammation. In humans and animals rolipram produces thereby a variety of biol. effects. These effects include attenuation of endogenous depression and inflammation in the central nervous system (CNS), both effects are of potential clin. relevance. There are some discrepancies between in vitro and in vivo effects of rolipram, as well as between results obtained in animal models and clin. studies. The clin. use of rolipram is limited because of its behavioral and other side effects. Newly developed selective PDE IV inhibitors with presumably higher potency and lower toxicity are currently under investigation.

Water enables new catalytic reactions for otherwise unreactive substrate systems. Under the "on water" reaction conditions, extremely unreactive β,β-disubstituted nitroalkenes smoothly underwent enantioselective Michael addn. reactions with dithiomalonates using a chiral squaramide catalyst, affording both enantiomers of highly enantioenriched Michael adducts with all-carbon-substituted quaternary centers. The developed "on water" protocol was successfully applied for the scalable one-pot syntheses of chiral GABA analogs with all-carbon quaternary stereogenic centers at the β-position, which might show highly interesting pharmaceutical properties.

Bae, Han Yong; Song, Choong Eui

In this study, water was demonstrated to be an exceptionally efficient reaction medium for the noncovalent, hydrogen-bonding-promoted enantioselective Michael addn. of malonates to diverse nitroolefins using cinchona-based squaramide catalysts. A significant increase in the reaction rate was obsd. when the reaction was performed "on water" rather than in the conventional org. solvents, because of the hydrophobic hydration effect. This hydrophobic amplification was significantly dependent upon the hydrophobicity of the C3-substituent (vinyl or ethyl) of cinchona-based catalysts. Thus, the use of more hydrophobic catalyst with an Et group at the C3-position, even a highly challenging Michael donor such as di-Me methylmalonate was also smoothly converted to the desired adduct. Furthermore, because of the remarkable rate acceleration under "on water" conditions, the catalyst loading also significantly decreased. Thus, in the case of β-ketoesters, even 0.01 mol % of catalyst loading was enough to complete the reaction at room temp., affording the corresponding Michael adducts with perfect diastereo- and enantioselectivity (up to >99:1 d.r., up to 99% ee). The developed "on water" protocol was successfully applied for the scalable syntheses of an antidepressant (S)-rolipram and an anticonvulsant (S)-pregabalin.

β-Substituted chiral γ-aminobutyric acids feature important biol. activities and are valuable intermediates for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals. Herein, an efficient catalytic enantioselective approach for the synthesis of β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid derivs. through visible-light-induced photocatalyst-free asym. radical conjugate addns. is reported. Various β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid analogs, including previously inaccessible derivs. contg. fluorinated quaternary stereocenters, were obtained in good yields (42-89 %) and with excellent enantioselectivity (90-97 % ee). Synthetically valuable applications were demonstrated by providing straightforward synthetic access to the pharmaceuticals or related bioactive compds. (S)-pregabalin, (R)-baclofen, (R)-rolipram, and (S)-nebracetam.

Asymmetric catalytic formation of quaternary carbons by iminium ion trapping of radicals
Murphy, John J.; Bastida, David; Paria, Suva; Fagnoni, Maurizio; Melchiorre, Paolo
Nature (London, United Kingdom)

An important goal of modern org. chem. is to develop new catalytic strategies for enantioselective carbon-carbon bond formation that can be used to generate quaternary stereogenic centers. Whereas considerable advances have been achieved by exploiting polar reactivity, radical transformations have been far less successful. This is despite the fact that open-shell intermediates are intrinsically primed for connecting structurally congested carbons, as their reactivity is only marginally affected by steric factors. Here we show how the combination of photoredox and asym. org. catalysis enables enantioselective radical conjugate addns. to β,β-disubstituted cyclic enones to obtain quaternary carbon stereocenters with high fidelity. Crit. to our success was the design of a chiral org. catalyst, contg. a redox-active carbazole moiety, that drives the formation of iminium ions and the stereoselective trapping of photochem. generated carbon-centered radicals by means of an electron-relay mechanism. We demonstrate the generality of this organocatalytic radical-trapping strategy with two sets of open-shell intermediates, formed through unrelated light-triggered pathways from readily available substrates and photoredox catalysts-this method represents the application of iminium ion activation (a successful catalytic strategy for enantioselective polar chem.) within the realm of radical reactivity.

A novel strategy with simultaneous utilization of both alkyl and carboxyl components from carboxylic acids was reported. Carboxylic acids acted as bifunctional reagents in redox-neutral carbo-carboxylation of alkenes. Diverse inexpensive and readily available α-AAs took part in such difunctionalizations of activated alkenes via visible-light photoredox catalysis, afforded a variety of valuable but otherwise difficult-to-access γ-aminobutyric acid derivs. (GABAs), e.g., I. Addnl., a series of dipeptides and tripeptides also participated in this photocatalytic carbo-carboxylation. Although several challenges exist in this system due to low concn. and quant. amt. of CO2, as well as unproductive side reactions such as hydrodecarboxylation of carboxylic acids and hydroalkylation of alkenes, excellent regioselectivity and moderate-to-high chemoselectivity were achieved. This process featured low catalyst loading, mild reaction conditions, high step- and atom-economy, good functional group tolerance, and it is readily scalable. The resulting products were subject to efficient derivations and overall process is amenable for applications in late-stage modification of complex compds. Mechanistic studies indicated that a carbanion was generated catalytically and it acted as key intermediate to react with CO2, which was also generated catalytically in situ and thus remains in low concn. The overall transformation represented an efficient and sustainable system for org. synthesis, pharmaceutics and biochem.

Transition metal-free phosphonocarboxylation of alkenes with carbon dioxide via visible-light photoredox catalysis
Fu Qiang; Bo Zhi-Yu; Ye Jian-Heng; Ju Tao; Huang He; Liao Li-Li; Yu Da-Gang; Fu Qiang; Yu Da-Gang

Catalytic difunctionalization of alkenes has been an ideal strategy to generate structurally complex molecules with diverse substitution patterns. Although both phosphonyl and carboxyl groups are valuable functional groups, the simultaneous incorporation of them via catalytic difunctionalization of alkenes, ideally from abundant, inexpensive and easy-to-handle raw materials, has not been realized. Herein, we report the phosphonocarboxylation of alkenes with CO2 via visible-light photoredox catalysis. This strategy is sustainable, general and practical, providing facile access to important β-phosphono carboxylic acids, including structurally complex unnatural α-amino acids. Diverse alkenes, including enamides, styrenes, enolsilanes and acrylates, undergo such reactions efficiently under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, this method represents a rare example of redox-neutral difunctionalization of alkenes with H-P(O) compounds, including diaryl- and dialkyl- phosphine oxides and phosphites. Importantly, these transition-metal-free reactions also feature low catalyst loading, high regio- and chemo-selectivities, good functional group tolerance, easy scalability and potential for product derivatization.

We herein developed a visible-light-promoted metal-free difunctionalization of alkenes using abundant CO2 and readily available Si-H and C(sp3)-H bonds as feedstocks. Through the merger of photoredox and hydrogen-atom-transfer catalysis, a variety of value-added compds., such as β-silacarboxylic acids and acids bearing a γ-heteroatom (e.g., N, O, S) could be directly accessed from simple alkenes in a redox-neutral fashion.

A review. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important C1 source for the generation of important carboxylic acids and derivs. Stoichiometric and catalytic carboxylation of nucleophiles, including organometallic reagents, with CO2 has been widely investigated. Since many kinds of organometallic reagents are prepd. from electrophiles, transition metal-catalyzed direct carboxylation of diverse electrophiles with CO2 has attracted much attention with high step economy and user-friendly protocols. Although significant progress has been achieved, the use of stoichiometric metallic or pyrophoric reductants is common. The renaissance of photochem. has seen numerous efforts devoted to light-driven carboxylation with CO2, which has become one of the most active directions in this field. In this Perspective, recent advances of visible light-driven catalytic reductive carboxylation of diverse substrates, such as unsatd. hydrocarbons, org. (pseudo)halides and imines, with CO2 in the presence of mild electron donors, including amines, Hantzsch esters and formates is discussed. The mechanisms of such reactions, which can proceed in the presence or absence of a photoredox catalyst, or a dual visible light photoredox/transition metal catalytic system is highlighted.

Radical-type difunctionalization of alkenes with CO2
Zhang, Zhen; Gong, Li; Zhou, Xiaoyu; Yan, Sishun; Li, Jing; Yu, Dagang

CO2 is an ideal C1 source in chem. transformations. It is of great significance to utilize CO2 in chem. conversion to synthesize high value-added compds., including carboxylic acids and carbonyl-contg. heterocycles. On the other hand, the difunctionalization of olefins is an important org. reaction, which can efficiently convert easily available olefins into important compds. with structural diversity. However, due to the low reactivity of CO2 and the difficulty in controlling the selectivity, the difunctionalization of olefins with CO2 is highly challenging. Recently, the significant progress of radical chem. has provided new strategies and promoted the development of novel transformations in this field. This Perspective summarizes the recent progress of the radical-type difunctionalization of olefins with CO2, including the oxy-alkylation, carbocarboxylation, silacarboxylation, thiocarboxylation, and dicarboxylation of alkenes with CO2. At the same time, we also highlight the mechanism with radicals and four kinds of pathways are proposed: (1) Free radicals attack olefins to form new carbon radical intermediates. The radicals are then oxidized to form carbocations, which are further captured by carbonates or carbamates. It is also possible for direct C-O bonding reaction or sequent C-I and C-O bonds formation. (2) The new carbon radical intermediates, in-situ generated through attack of alkenes with radicals, are reduced via single electron transfer into carbanions, which could attack CO2 to form C-C bonds. (3) CO2 is reduced into CO2 radical anions in the highly reductive reaction conditions. Once generated, the CO2 radical anions might attack olefins to form carboxylate bearing more stable carbon radical intermediates (such as benzylic ones) and further form C-C bonds or carbon-heteroatom bonds. (4) Olefins are reduced via single electron transfer into alkenyl free radical anions in the highly reductive reaction conditions. These anions may attack CO2 to form carboxylate bearing carbon radical intermediates and are further reduced to generate carbanions. Finally they may attack another CO2 to form succinic acid derivs. We point out the challenges and predict the future development in the field, including the more challenging substrates, more reaction types, better selectivities, and deeper mechanistic understanding.

A review. More than 50 years have passed since Haszeldine reported the first addn. of a trifluoromethyl radical to an allene; in the intervening years, both the chem. of allenes and the reactivity of single-electron species have become topics of intense interest. In this Review, we provide an overview of the fundamentals of radical addns. to allenes and highlight the emergence of theor. and exptl. evidence that reveals unique reactivity patterns for radical addns. to allenes as compared with other unsatd. compds. Factors capable of exerting control over the chemo-, regio-, and stereoselectivities of the attack of carbon- and heteroatom-based radicals at each of the three potential reactive sites in an allene substrate are described. These include reaction conditions, the nature of the attacking radical, the substitution pattern of the allene, and the length of the linker between the radical center and the proximal allene carbon in the substrate. Cycloaddn. reactions between allenes and partners contg. π-bonds, which are likely to proceed through radical pathways, are presented to highlight their ability to rapidly access complex polycyclic scaffolds. Finally, the synthetic utility of the products arising from these chemistries is described, including their applications to the construction of complex mols.

This review describes electrophilic reactions of allenes with defined regio- and stereoselectivity developed in our lab. Modern org. synthesis depends on the development of highly selective methods for the efficient construction of potentially useful target mols. A primary goal in our lab. is the discovery of new reactions that convert readily available starting materials to complex products with complete control of regio- and stereoselectivity. Allenes are one underused moiety in org. synthesis, because these groups are often thought to be highly reactive. However, many compds. contg. the allene group, including natural products and pharmaceuticals, are fairly stable. The chem. of allenes has been shown to have significant potential in org. synthesis. Electrophilic addns. to allenes have often been considered to be synthetically less attractive due to the lack of efficient control of the regio- and stereoselectivity. Many substituted allenes are readily available from propargylic alcs. Our work has involved an exploration of the reactions of these allenes with many different electrophiles: the E- or Z-halo- or seleno-hydroxylations of allenyl sulfoxides, sulfones, phosphine oxides, carboxylates, sulfides or selenides, butenolides, and arenes, and the halo- or selenolactonization reactions of allenoic acids and allenoates. These reactions have produced a host of new compds. such as stereodefined allylic alcs., ethers, amides, thiiranes, and lactones. In all these reactions, water acts as a reactant and plays an important role in detg. the reaction pathway and the stereoselectivity. The differing electronic properties of the two C=C bonds in these allenes det. the regioselectivity of these reactions. Through mechanistic studies of chirality transfer, isolation and reactivity of cyclic intermediates, 18O-labeling, and substituent effects, we discovered that the E-stereoselectivity of some reactions results from the neighboring group participation of functional groups forming cyclic intermediates. We rationalize Z-stereoselectivity under other conditions by soft Lewis acid-base interactions and steric effects. These electrophilic reactions of allenes are efficient and useful methods for the synthesis of stereodefined alkenes and lactones, useful functionalities for synthesis.

The alkylative carboxylation of allenamide catalyzed by an N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-copper(I) complex [(IPr)CuCl] with CO2 and dialkylzinc reagents was investigated. The reaction of allenamides with dialkylzinc reagents (1.5 equiv) and CO2 (1 atm.) proceeded smoothly in the presence of a catalytic quantity of [(IPr)CuCl] to afford (Z)-α,β-dehydro-β-amino acid esters e.g., I in good yields. The reaction is regioselective, with the alkyl group introduced onto the less hindered γ-carbon, and the carboxyl group introduced onto the β-carbon atom of the allenamides. The first step of the reaction was alkylative zincation of the allenamides to give an alkenylzinc intermediate followed by nucleophilic addn. to CO2. A variety of cyclic and acyclic allenamides were found to be applicable to this transformation. Dialkylzinc reagents bearing β-hydrogen atoms, such as Et2Zn or Bu2Zn, also gave the corresponding alkylative carboxylation products without β-hydride elimination. The present methodol. provides an easy route to alkyl-substituted α,β-dehydro-β-amino acid ester derivs. under mild reaction conditions with high regio- and stereoselectivity.

Arylative carboxylation of allenes proceeded in an intramol. manner to afford the corresponding β,γ-unsatd. carboxylic acids, e.g., I, in high yields using PdCl2/PAr3 (Ar = C6H4-p-CF3) and ZnEt2 under 1 atm of CO2. A regiodivergent silacarboxylation of allenes under a CO2 atmosphere with PhMe2Si-B(pin) as a silicon source in the presence of a copper catalyst at 70° has been developed. The regioselectivity of the reaction is successfully reversed by the proper choice of ligand; carboxylated vinylsilanes are obtained with rac-Me-DuPhos as the ligand, whereas the use of PCy3 affords carboxylated allylsilanes. Thus, two different carboxylated silanes can be selectively and regiodivergently synthesized from a single allene substrate.

A review. Single electron oxidn. of amines provides an efficient way to access synthetically useful α-aminoalkyl radicals as reactive intermediates. After the single electron oxidn. of amines, fragmentation of the resulting radical cations proceeds to give the α-aminoalkyl radicals along with generation of a proton. In the synthetic utilization of the α-aminoalkyl radicals, precise control of single electron transfer is essential, because further oxidn. of the α-aminoalkyl radicals occurs more easily than the starting amines and the α-aminoalkyl radicals are converted into the corresponding iminium ions. As a result, photoinduced single electron transfer is quite attractive in the synthetic utilization of the α-aminoalkyl radicals. Recently, visible light-photoredox catalysis using transition metal-polypyridyl complexes and other dyes as catalysts has attracted considerable attention, where useful mol. transformations can be achieved through the single electron transfer process between the excited catalysts and substrates. In this context, MacMillan et al. (Science 2011, 334, 1114, DOI: 10.1126/science.1213920) reported an arom. substitution reaction of cyanoarenes with amines, where α-aminoalkyl radicals work as key reactive intermediates. Pandey and Reiser et al. (Org. Lett. 2012, 14, 672, DOI: 10.1021/ol202857t) and our group (Nishibayashi et al. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 3338, DOI: 10.1021/ja211770y) independently reported reactions of amines with α,β-unsatd. carbonyl compds., where addn. of α-aminoalkyl radicals to alkenes is a key step. After these earliest examples, nowadays, a variety of transformations using the α-aminoalkyl radicals as reactive intermediates have been reported by many groups. The α-aminoalkyl radicals are usually produced from amines by single electron oxidn. and the subsequent deprotonation of the C-H bond adjacent to the nitrogen atom. In addn., the α-aminoalkyl radicals are also produced from α-silylamines and α-amino acids in high efficiency through desilylation or decarboxylation after the single electron oxidn. The generated α-aminoalkyl radicals are utilized in a variety of reaction systems. In fact, reactions based on the addn. of α-aminoalkyl radicals to alkenes and other unsatd. bonds have been extensively studied. Arom. and other types of substitution reactions have also been investigated. Some of these transformations are achieved by combination of photoredox catalysts and other catalysts such as Bronsted and Lewis acids, organocatalysts, and transition metal catalysts. It is also noteworthy that the enantioselective reactions have been accomplished by combination of photoredox catalysts and chiral catalysts. The strategy for the generation of α-aminoalkyl radicals can be applied to utilize other types of alkyl radicals. In the generation of α-aminoalkyl radicals, the bond dissocn. of the radical cations occurs at the α-position of amines. In relation to this process, synthetic utilization of other types of alkyl radicals generated by the bond dissocn. of the radical cations at a remote position has been also investigated. These alkyl radicals have been applied to mol. transformations in a manner similar to the α-aminoalkyl radicals. Recently, org. synthesis using the α-aminoalkyl radicals and related alkyl radicals has been studied extensively. In this Account, we describe recent advances in photoredox-catalyzed synthetic utilization of these alkyl radicals.

Stress-induced elevations of γ-aminobutyric acid type A receptor-active steroids in the rat brain
Purdy, Robert H.; Morrow, A. Leslie; Moore, Perry H, Jr.; Paul, Steven M.
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
(
1991
),
88
(
10
),
4553-7
CODEN:
PNASA6
; ISSN:
0027-8424
.
A 3α-hydroxy A-ring-reduced metabolite of progesterone, 3α-hydroxy-5α-pregnan-20-one (allopregnanolone), and one of deoxycorticosterone (DOC), 3α,21-dihydroxy-5α-pregnan-20-one (allotetrahydroDOC), are among the most potent known ligands of γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA) receptors designated GABAA in the central nervous system. With specific RIAs, rapid (<5 min) and robust (4-20-fold) increases of allopregnanolone and allotetrahydroDOC were detected in the brain (cerebral cortex and hypothalamus) and in plasma of rats after exposure to ambient temp. swim stress. Neither steroid was detectable in the plasma of adrenalectomized rats either before or after swim stress. However, allopregnanolone, but not allotetrahydroDOC, was still present in the cerebral cortex (>3 ng/g) after adrenalectomy. These data demonstrate the presence of allopregnanolone and allotetrahydroDOC in brain and show that acute stress results in a rapid increase of these neuroactive steroids to levels known to modulate GABAA receptor function.

A review with refs. γ-Amino acids have attracted considerable attention as biol. active compds. in the central nervous system (CNS) of mammals. Over the last few years, significant interest in the stereoselective synthesis and practical application of linear and cyclic chiral γ-amino acids in the synthesis and design of α,β- and β,γ-hybrid peptides with definite secondary structures and design of nanotubes has been reported, thus demonstrating the theor. interest and the practical importance of γ-amino acids. An overview of synthetic approaches to linear and cyclic chiral γ-amino acids and derivs. is presented. Data on the practical applications of γ-amino acids are also discussed.

A review. The anticonvulsant drug (S)-(+)-3-isobutyl-γ-aminobutyric acid ((S)-(+)-3-isobutyl-GABA, Lyrica) was developed from a study of fundamental science, which took an unexpected course. The activity of Lyrica was found to be unrelated to the originally anticipated activation of L-glutamic acid decarboxylase and the increase in the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA; instead, it antagonizes a calcium ion channel, which inhibits the release of the excitatory neurotransmitter L-glutamate. The ultimate effect, however, is the same.

Sachais B A; Logue J N; Carey M S

A double-blind, five-week, multicenter trial was conducted to compare the effect of baclofen, a unique amino acid derivative, with that of placebo in the treatment of 106 patients with spasticity secondary to multiple sclerosis. A spasticity assessment method that included a neurological examination, physicians' clinical impressions of changes during treatment, and a patient's self-evaluation was used to determine efficacy. This method showed baclofen (70 to 80 mg daily maximum, titrated) is effective relative to placebo in relieving symptoms of spasticity, such as flexor spasms, pain and stiffness, resistance to passive joint movements, and tendon stretch reflexes. Patient self-evaluation results also showed a significant reduction in clonus. Side effects were generally mild and transient.

A review. Phenibut (β-phenyl-γ-aminobutyric acid HCl) is a neuro-psychotropic drug that was discovered and introduced into clin. practice in Russia in the 1960s. It has anxiolytic and nootropic (cognition enhancing) effects. It acts as a GABA-mimetic, primarily at GABAB and, to some extent, at GABAA receptors. It also stimulates dopamine receptors and antagonizes β-phenethylamine (PEA), a putative endogenous anxiogenic. The psychopharmacol. activity of phenibut is similar to that of baclofen, a p-Cl-deriv. of phenibut. This article reviews the structure-activity relationship of phenibut and its derivs. Emphasis is placed on the importance of the position of the Ph ring, the role of the carboxyl group, and the activity of optical isomers. Comparison of phenibut with piracetam and diazepam reveals similarities and differences in their pharmacol. and clin. effects. Phenibut is widely used in Russia to relieve tension, anxiety, and fear, to improve sleep in psychosomatic or neurotic patients; as well as a pre- or post-operative medication. It is also used in the therapy of disorders characterized by asthenia and depression, as well as in post-traumatic stress, stuttering, and vestibular disorders.

Zhu, Jie; Mix, Eilhard; Winblad, Bengt

A review. Rolipram is a selective inhibitor of phosphodiesterases (PDE) IV, esp. of the subtype PDE IVB. These phosphodiesterases are responsible for hydrolysis of the cyclic nucleotides cAMP and cGMP, particularly in nerve and immune cells. Consequences of rolipram-induced elevation of intracellular cAMP are increased synthesis and release of norepinephrine, which enhance central noradrenergic transmission, and suppress expression of proinflammatory cytokines and other mediators of inflammation. In humans and animals rolipram produces thereby a variety of biol. effects. These effects include attenuation of endogenous depression and inflammation in the central nervous system (CNS), both effects are of potential clin. relevance. There are some discrepancies between in vitro and in vivo effects of rolipram, as well as between results obtained in animal models and clin. studies. The clin. use of rolipram is limited because of its behavioral and other side effects. Newly developed selective PDE IV inhibitors with presumably higher potency and lower toxicity are currently under investigation.

Water enables new catalytic reactions for otherwise unreactive substrate systems. Under the "on water" reaction conditions, extremely unreactive β,β-disubstituted nitroalkenes smoothly underwent enantioselective Michael addn. reactions with dithiomalonates using a chiral squaramide catalyst, affording both enantiomers of highly enantioenriched Michael adducts with all-carbon-substituted quaternary centers. The developed "on water" protocol was successfully applied for the scalable one-pot syntheses of chiral GABA analogs with all-carbon quaternary stereogenic centers at the β-position, which might show highly interesting pharmaceutical properties.

Unprecedented Hydrophobic Amplification in Noncovalent Organocatalysis "on Water": Hydrophobic Chiral Squaramide Catalyzed Michael Addition of Malonates to Nitroalkenes
Bae, Han Yong; Song, Choong Eui

In this study, water was demonstrated to be an exceptionally efficient reaction medium for the noncovalent, hydrogen-bonding-promoted enantioselective Michael addn. of malonates to diverse nitroolefins using cinchona-based squaramide catalysts. A significant increase in the reaction rate was obsd. when the reaction was performed "on water" rather than in the conventional org. solvents, because of the hydrophobic hydration effect. This hydrophobic amplification was significantly dependent upon the hydrophobicity of the C3-substituent (vinyl or ethyl) of cinchona-based catalysts. Thus, the use of more hydrophobic catalyst with an Et group at the C3-position, even a highly challenging Michael donor such as di-Me methylmalonate was also smoothly converted to the desired adduct. Furthermore, because of the remarkable rate acceleration under "on water" conditions, the catalyst loading also significantly decreased. Thus, in the case of β-ketoesters, even 0.01 mol % of catalyst loading was enough to complete the reaction at room temp., affording the corresponding Michael adducts with perfect diastereo- and enantioselectivity (up to >99:1 d.r., up to 99% ee). The developed "on water" protocol was successfully applied for the scalable syntheses of an antidepressant (S)-rolipram and an anticonvulsant (S)-pregabalin.

β-Substituted chiral γ-aminobutyric acids feature important biol. activities and are valuable intermediates for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals. Herein, an efficient catalytic enantioselective approach for the synthesis of β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid derivs. through visible-light-induced photocatalyst-free asym. radical conjugate addns. is reported. Various β-substituted γ-aminobutyric acid analogs, including previously inaccessible derivs. contg. fluorinated quaternary stereocenters, were obtained in good yields (42-89 %) and with excellent enantioselectivity (90-97 % ee). Synthetically valuable applications were demonstrated by providing straightforward synthetic access to the pharmaceuticals or related bioactive compds. (S)-pregabalin, (R)-baclofen, (R)-rolipram, and (S)-nebracetam.

An important goal of modern org. chem. is to develop new catalytic strategies for enantioselective carbon-carbon bond formation that can be used to generate quaternary stereogenic centers. Whereas considerable advances have been achieved by exploiting polar reactivity, radical transformations have been far less successful. This is despite the fact that open-shell intermediates are intrinsically primed for connecting structurally congested carbons, as their reactivity is only marginally affected by steric factors. Here we show how the combination of photoredox and asym. org. catalysis enables enantioselective radical conjugate addns. to β,β-disubstituted cyclic enones to obtain quaternary carbon stereocenters with high fidelity. Crit. to our success was the design of a chiral org. catalyst, contg. a redox-active carbazole moiety, that drives the formation of iminium ions and the stereoselective trapping of photochem. generated carbon-centered radicals by means of an electron-relay mechanism. We demonstrate the generality of this organocatalytic radical-trapping strategy with two sets of open-shell intermediates, formed through unrelated light-triggered pathways from readily available substrates and photoredox catalysts-this method represents the application of iminium ion activation (a successful catalytic strategy for enantioselective polar chem.) within the realm of radical reactivity.

A novel strategy with simultaneous utilization of both alkyl and carboxyl components from carboxylic acids was reported. Carboxylic acids acted as bifunctional reagents in redox-neutral carbo-carboxylation of alkenes. Diverse inexpensive and readily available α-AAs took part in such difunctionalizations of activated alkenes via visible-light photoredox catalysis, afforded a variety of valuable but otherwise difficult-to-access γ-aminobutyric acid derivs. (GABAs), e.g., I. Addnl., a series of dipeptides and tripeptides also participated in this photocatalytic carbo-carboxylation. Although several challenges exist in this system due to low concn. and quant. amt. of CO2, as well as unproductive side reactions such as hydrodecarboxylation of carboxylic acids and hydroalkylation of alkenes, excellent regioselectivity and moderate-to-high chemoselectivity were achieved. This process featured low catalyst loading, mild reaction conditions, high step- and atom-economy, good functional group tolerance, and it is readily scalable. The resulting products were subject to efficient derivations and overall process is amenable for applications in late-stage modification of complex compds. Mechanistic studies indicated that a carbanion was generated catalytically and it acted as key intermediate to react with CO2, which was also generated catalytically in situ and thus remains in low concn. The overall transformation represented an efficient and sustainable system for org. synthesis, pharmaceutics and biochem.

Catalytic difunctionalization of alkenes has been an ideal strategy to generate structurally complex molecules with diverse substitution patterns. Although both phosphonyl and carboxyl groups are valuable functional groups, the simultaneous incorporation of them via catalytic difunctionalization of alkenes, ideally from abundant, inexpensive and easy-to-handle raw materials, has not been realized. Herein, we report the phosphonocarboxylation of alkenes with CO2 via visible-light photoredox catalysis. This strategy is sustainable, general and practical, providing facile access to important β-phosphono carboxylic acids, including structurally complex unnatural α-amino acids. Diverse alkenes, including enamides, styrenes, enolsilanes and acrylates, undergo such reactions efficiently under mild reaction conditions. Moreover, this method represents a rare example of redox-neutral difunctionalization of alkenes with H-P(O) compounds, including diaryl- and dialkyl- phosphine oxides and phosphites. Importantly, these transition-metal-free reactions also feature low catalyst loading, high regio- and chemo-selectivities, good functional group tolerance, easy scalability and potential for product derivatization.

A review. Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an important C1 source for the generation of important carboxylic acids and derivs. Stoichiometric and catalytic carboxylation of nucleophiles, including organometallic reagents, with CO2 has been widely investigated. Since many kinds of organometallic reagents are prepd. from electrophiles, transition metal-catalyzed direct carboxylation of diverse electrophiles with CO2 has attracted much attention with high step economy and user-friendly protocols. Although significant progress has been achieved, the use of stoichiometric metallic or pyrophoric reductants is common. The renaissance of photochem. has seen numerous efforts devoted to light-driven carboxylation with CO2, which has become one of the most active directions in this field. In this Perspective, recent advances of visible light-driven catalytic reductive carboxylation of diverse substrates, such as unsatd. hydrocarbons, org. (pseudo)halides and imines, with CO2 in the presence of mild electron donors, including amines, Hantzsch esters and formates is discussed. The mechanisms of such reactions, which can proceed in the presence or absence of a photoredox catalyst, or a dual visible light photoredox/transition metal catalytic system is highlighted.

Radical-type difunctionalization of alkenes with CO2
Zhang, Zhen; Gong, Li; Zhou, Xiaoyu; Yan, Sishun; Li, Jing; Yu, Dagang
Huaxue Xuebao
(
2019
),
77
(
9
),
783-793
CODEN:
HHHPA4
; ISSN:
0567-7351
.
(
Huaxue Xuebao Bianjibu
)
CO2 is an ideal C1 source in chem. transformations. It is of great significance to utilize CO2 in chem. conversion to synthesize high value-added compds., including carboxylic acids and carbonyl-contg. heterocycles. On the other hand, the difunctionalization of olefins is an important org. reaction, which can efficiently convert easily available olefins into important compds. with structural diversity. However, due to the low reactivity of CO2 and the difficulty in controlling the selectivity, the difunctionalization of olefins with CO2 is highly challenging. Recently, the significant progress of radical chem. has provided new strategies and promoted the development of novel transformations in this field. This Perspective summarizes the recent progress of the radical-type difunctionalization of olefins with CO2, including the oxy-alkylation, carbocarboxylation, silacarboxylation, thiocarboxylation, and dicarboxylation of alkenes with CO2. At the same time, we also highlight the mechanism with radicals and four kinds of pathways are proposed: (1) Free radicals attack olefins to form new carbon radical intermediates. The radicals are then oxidized to form carbocations, which are further captured by carbonates or carbamates. It is also possible for direct C-O bonding reaction or sequent C-I and C-O bonds formation. (2) The new carbon radical intermediates, in-situ generated through attack of alkenes with radicals, are reduced via single electron transfer into carbanions, which could attack CO2 to form C-C bonds. (3) CO2 is reduced into CO2 radical anions in the highly reductive reaction conditions. Once generated, the CO2 radical anions might attack olefins to form carboxylate bearing more stable carbon radical intermediates (such as benzylic ones) and further form C-C bonds or carbon-heteroatom bonds. (4) Olefins are reduced via single electron transfer into alkenyl free radical anions in the highly reductive reaction conditions. These anions may attack CO2 to form carboxylate bearing carbon radical intermediates and are further reduced to generate carbanions. Finally they may attack another CO2 to form succinic acid derivs. We point out the challenges and predict the future development in the field, including the more challenging substrates, more reaction types, better selectivities, and deeper mechanistic understanding.

The first catalytic hydrocarboxylation of enamides and imines with CO2 to generate valuable α,α-disubstituted α-amino acids is reported. Notably, excellent chemo- and regio-selectivity are achieved, significantly different from previous reports on β-carboxylation of enamides, homocoupling or redn. of imines. Moreover, this transition-metal-free procedure exhibits low loading of an inexpensive catalyst, easily available substrates, mild reaction conditions, high efficiency, facile scalability and easy product derivatization, providing great potential for application in org. synthesis, pharmaceutical chem., and biochem.

A review. More than 50 years have passed since Haszeldine reported the first addn. of a trifluoromethyl radical to an allene; in the intervening years, both the chem. of allenes and the reactivity of single-electron species have become topics of intense interest. In this Review, we provide an overview of the fundamentals of radical addns. to allenes and highlight the emergence of theor. and exptl. evidence that reveals unique reactivity patterns for radical addns. to allenes as compared with other unsatd. compds. Factors capable of exerting control over the chemo-, regio-, and stereoselectivities of the attack of carbon- and heteroatom-based radicals at each of the three potential reactive sites in an allene substrate are described. These include reaction conditions, the nature of the attacking radical, the substitution pattern of the allene, and the length of the linker between the radical center and the proximal allene carbon in the substrate. Cycloaddn. reactions between allenes and partners contg. π-bonds, which are likely to proceed through radical pathways, are presented to highlight their ability to rapidly access complex polycyclic scaffolds. Finally, the synthetic utility of the products arising from these chemistries is described, including their applications to the construction of complex mols.

This review describes electrophilic reactions of allenes with defined regio- and stereoselectivity developed in our lab. Modern org. synthesis depends on the development of highly selective methods for the efficient construction of potentially useful target mols. A primary goal in our lab. is the discovery of new reactions that convert readily available starting materials to complex products with complete control of regio- and stereoselectivity. Allenes are one underused moiety in org. synthesis, because these groups are often thought to be highly reactive. However, many compds. contg. the allene group, including natural products and pharmaceuticals, are fairly stable. The chem. of allenes has been shown to have significant potential in org. synthesis. Electrophilic addns. to allenes have often been considered to be synthetically less attractive due to the lack of efficient control of the regio- and stereoselectivity. Many substituted allenes are readily available from propargylic alcs. Our work has involved an exploration of the reactions of these allenes with many different electrophiles: the E- or Z-halo- or seleno-hydroxylations of allenyl sulfoxides, sulfones, phosphine oxides, carboxylates, sulfides or selenides, butenolides, and arenes, and the halo- or selenolactonization reactions of allenoic acids and allenoates. These reactions have produced a host of new compds. such as stereodefined allylic alcs., ethers, amides, thiiranes, and lactones. In all these reactions, water acts as a reactant and plays an important role in detg. the reaction pathway and the stereoselectivity. The differing electronic properties of the two C=C bonds in these allenes det. the regioselectivity of these reactions. Through mechanistic studies of chirality transfer, isolation and reactivity of cyclic intermediates, 18O-labeling, and substituent effects, we discovered that the E-stereoselectivity of some reactions results from the neighboring group participation of functional groups forming cyclic intermediates. We rationalize Z-stereoselectivity under other conditions by soft Lewis acid-base interactions and steric effects. These electrophilic reactions of allenes are efficient and useful methods for the synthesis of stereodefined alkenes and lactones, useful functionalities for synthesis.

The alkylative carboxylation of allenamide catalyzed by an N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC)-copper(I) complex [(IPr)CuCl] with CO2 and dialkylzinc reagents was investigated. The reaction of allenamides with dialkylzinc reagents (1.5 equiv) and CO2 (1 atm.) proceeded smoothly in the presence of a catalytic quantity of [(IPr)CuCl] to afford (Z)-α,β-dehydro-β-amino acid esters e.g., I in good yields. The reaction is regioselective, with the alkyl group introduced onto the less hindered γ-carbon, and the carboxyl group introduced onto the β-carbon atom of the allenamides. The first step of the reaction was alkylative zincation of the allenamides to give an alkenylzinc intermediate followed by nucleophilic addn. to CO2. A variety of cyclic and acyclic allenamides were found to be applicable to this transformation. Dialkylzinc reagents bearing β-hydrogen atoms, such as Et2Zn or Bu2Zn, also gave the corresponding alkylative carboxylation products without β-hydride elimination. The present methodol. provides an easy route to alkyl-substituted α,β-dehydro-β-amino acid ester derivs. under mild reaction conditions with high regio- and stereoselectivity.

16a
Synthetic Utilization of α-Aminoalkyl Radicals and Related Species in Visible Light Photoredox Catalysis
Nakajima, Kazunari; Miyake, Yoshihiro; Nishibayashi, Yoshiaki
Accounts of Chemical Research
(
2016
),
49
(
9
),
1946-1956
CODEN:
ACHRE4
; ISSN:
0001-4842
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
A review. Single electron oxidn. of amines provides an efficient way to access synthetically useful α-aminoalkyl radicals as reactive intermediates. After the single electron oxidn. of amines, fragmentation of the resulting radical cations proceeds to give the α-aminoalkyl radicals along with generation of a proton. In the synthetic utilization of the α-aminoalkyl radicals, precise control of single electron transfer is essential, because further oxidn. of the α-aminoalkyl radicals occurs more easily than the starting amines and the α-aminoalkyl radicals are converted into the corresponding iminium ions. As a result, photoinduced single electron transfer is quite attractive in the synthetic utilization of the α-aminoalkyl radicals. Recently, visible light-photoredox catalysis using transition metal-polypyridyl complexes and other dyes as catalysts has attracted considerable attention, where useful mol. transformations can be achieved through the single electron transfer process between the excited catalysts and substrates. In this context, MacMillan et al. (Science 2011, 334, 1114, DOI: 10.1126/science.1213920) reported an arom. substitution reaction of cyanoarenes with amines, where α-aminoalkyl radicals work as key reactive intermediates. Pandey and Reiser et al. (Org. Lett. 2012, 14, 672, DOI: 10.1021/ol202857t) and our group (Nishibayashi et al. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2012, 134, 3338, DOI: 10.1021/ja211770y) independently reported reactions of amines with α,β-unsatd. carbonyl compds., where addn. of α-aminoalkyl radicals to alkenes is a key step. After these earliest examples, nowadays, a variety of transformations using the α-aminoalkyl radicals as reactive intermediates have been reported by many groups. The α-aminoalkyl radicals are usually produced from amines by single electron oxidn. and the subsequent deprotonation of the C-H bond adjacent to the nitrogen atom. In addn., the α-aminoalkyl radicals are also produced from α-silylamines and α-amino acids in high efficiency through desilylation or decarboxylation after the single electron oxidn. The generated α-aminoalkyl radicals are utilized in a variety of reaction systems. In fact, reactions based on the addn. of α-aminoalkyl radicals to alkenes and other unsatd. bonds have been extensively studied. Arom. and other types of substitution reactions have also been investigated. Some of these transformations are achieved by combination of photoredox catalysts and other catalysts such as Bronsted and Lewis acids, organocatalysts, and transition metal catalysts. It is also noteworthy that the enantioselective reactions have been accomplished by combination of photoredox catalysts and chiral catalysts. The strategy for the generation of α-aminoalkyl radicals can be applied to utilize other types of alkyl radicals. In the generation of α-aminoalkyl radicals, the bond dissocn. of the radical cations occurs at the α-position of amines. In relation to this process, synthetic utilization of other types of alkyl radicals generated by the bond dissocn. of the radical cations at a remote position has been also investigated. These alkyl radicals have been applied to mol. transformations in a manner similar to the α-aminoalkyl radicals. Recently, org. synthesis using the α-aminoalkyl radicals and related alkyl radicals has been studied extensively. In this Account, we describe recent advances in photoredox-catalyzed synthetic utilization of these alkyl radicals.

A silver(I) catalyzed regioselective trifluoromethylation of allenes using Langlois's salt (NaOSOCF3) is demonstrated. This transformation enables direct expedient access to α-trifluoromethylated acroleins, which are valuable synthons for a no. of pharmaceuticals and agrochems. contg. vinyl-CF3 moieties. Versatility of this trifluoromethylation method has been established with good yield and excellent regioselectivity. Preliminary expts. and computational studies were carried out to elucidate the mechanistic insight of this protocol.

This practical reaction is fast, operationally simple, and in particular, proceeds under very mild conditions to afford the target products with high regio- and stereoselectivity. A novel oxytrifluoromethylation of aryl-substituted allenes by photoredox catalysis was developed. The present photocatalytic system allowed direct and stereoselective synthesis of 2-CF3-allyl acetates bearing tetrasubstituted CF3-alkene scaffolds in a single operation. The obtained CF3-allyl acetates can be applied to further functionalization as CF3-contg. building blocks.
